book.name: Instructional Strategies
book.intro:
We wrap up this lesson by exploring our fourth and final guiding question:

What are some strategies for teaching ELLs with possible or identified LD?

chapter.title: Elements of a comprehensive evaluation
chapter.content:
What are some strategies for teaching ELLs with possible or identified LD?

Instructors of adult ELLs may wonder whether a certain student has a learning disability that is impeding his or her progress in English. Yet many of us work in settings where we do not have ready access to consultation, guidance, or referral advice and special needs professionals to address these concerns.

To further complicate the classroom setting, language challenges are exacerbated for ELL students with LD because they are struggling not just in one, but two different languages.  The responsibility then falls on teachers to make sure the classroom environment is not the cause for learning breakdown.

This topic includes some suggestions of what an instructor can do when teaching to a culturally and linguistically diverse class.

chapter.title: Strategies for teaching a diverse class of ELLs with LD
chapter.content:
Here are a few classroom strategies instructors can employ when teaching a linguistically and culturally diverse class of adult ELL students with LD.

  • Reduce the level of distraction in the room.
  • Provide additional time whenever possible. Students with LD may require extra time to complete in-class and homework assignments as well as tests.
  • Consider administering tests in alternative formats, such as orally or on the computer.
  • Whenever appropriate, present material using graphics and/or sensory media.
  • Combine both auditory and visual stimuli when possible. For example, say directions  and write them on the board.
  • Have students use a word processor to whatever extent is possible. Because word processing makes rewriting and revising so much less laborious, its value is immeasurable for those students with fine-motor, sequencing, spelling, and other language manipulation problems.
  • Make it easy for students to ask for repetition and bear in mind that it is important to use the same language when you do repeat so that you do not change the construction and defeat the purpose of the repetition.
  • Allow time in advance for students to think about items to be covered in class. Provide plenty of pre-discussion, pre-writing, pre-reading lead time, and other pre-teaching activities.
  • Don't jump without warning from one topic to another.
  • Explicitly state the topic at hand and proceed in a structured, concrete manner. Progress from the obvious to the concrete to the abstract.
  • Frame material by relating it to past classroom or personal experience and always highlight new material.
  • Don't issue too many instructions at the same time. Break tasks down into their component parts and issue the instructions for each part one at a time.

Have you used any of these strategies in your classroom instruction with ELLs with LDs? If so, share your experiences in the LINCS Community of Practice English Language Acquisition and Disabilities and Equitable Outcomes groups.

chapter.title: Assistive technology
chapter.content:
In addition to the instructional strategies you just reviewed, assistive technology can help improve functional capabilities of students with LD.  It can help ELLs with LD accomplish daily living tasks assisting them in communication, education, work, and recreational activities. In essence, assistive technology helps them achieve greater independence and enhance their quality of life.

According to the definition proposed in the Assistive Technology Act of 1998, "Assistive, or adaptive, technology commonly refers to products, devices, or equipment, whether acquired commercially, modified, or customized, that are used to maintain, increase, or improve the functional capabilities of individuals with disabilities..."

chapter.title: Examples of assistive technology
chapter.content:
Here are some examples of assistive technology that can be used in an instructional classroom setting.  

  • When using a computer, many ELLs with LD may find it helpful to use reading assistive technology software, such as a screen reader.
  • A screen reader is a software application that converts text to speech by reading the written contents of a computer screen. There are a variety of screen readers designed for specific operating systems. An example of free screen reader software is available from NV Access.
  • ELLs with LD may find it helpful to use talking word prediction software when typing on a computer.
  • Used along with standard writing software, talking Word prediction software can be beneficial to instruction. These programs use speech synthesizers to provide auditory feedback of what is typed. They also suggest words for you to use as you type and provide spoken feedback to help you find mistakes. This can help ELLS with LD that experience problems with writing and editing.

chapter.title: Language proficiency
chapter.content:
WIOA requires states to “align content standards with state-adopted challenging content standards.” English language proficiency standards are one essential component of a state-adopted standards approach. While each state determines the set of the standards appropriate for the state, the U.S. Department of Education supported the development of English Language Proficiency (ELP) Standards for Adult Education as one option to address the need for educational equity, access, and rigor for ELLs. ELP Standards are essential to ensure that adult ELLs receive the focused and effective instruction needed to access states’ academic content standards and ultimately acquire the language, knowledge, and skills necessary for success in postsecondary and career.

Explore Federal ELP Standards Resources

The Department of Education has developed many resources designed to assist states in the implementation of ELP standards, including:

  • English Language Proficiency Standards for Adult Education. This report is intended to support all educators who are teaching adult ELLs, including ELLs with disabilities.
  • A series of three online modules:
    • Introduction to the English Language Proficiency Standards for Adult Education –Module One 
    • Analyzing Student Tasks in Relation to Content Demands, Thinking Skills, and Language Use – Module Two
    • Digging Deeper into the English Language Proficiency Standards for Adult Education – Module Three

chapter.title: ELLs with LD have specific instructional needs
chapter.content:
ELLs with disabilities have specific instructional needs.

The ELP Standards for Adult Education have ten guiding principals that informed the development of the standards. Guiding principal #8 acknowledges that ELLs with disabilities have specific instructional needs.

  1. Adult ELLs have the potential to meet state-adopted challenging academic content standards.
  2. Adult ELLs represent a diverse population of learners.
  3. Adult ELLs’ funds of knowledge are a resource for their learning.
  4. Social language has an important role in ELLs’ English language acquisition process.
  5. Three key instructional advances form the basis of state-adopted content standards for English language arts in adult education that ELLs must access.
  6. Adult ELLs must be able to successfully engage with a wide variety of informational texts.
  7. Scaffolding is an essential tool to facilitate ELLs’ acquisition of language and content.
  8. ELLs with disabilities have specific instructional needs.
  9. Multimedia technology aligned to the ELP Standards for AE should be integrated into instruction.
  10. Academic language instruction should be incorporated into all content lessons, including mathematics and science.

 

Source: U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical and Adult Education. Adult English Language Proficiency Standards for Adult Education. Washington, DC, 2016.
